## The "Normal Pathology" Thesis

::: fragment
**Key Premise**

Far-right parties represent *abnormal* values alien to Western democratic culture
:::

. . .

::: fragment
**Research question derived:**

"Under what extreme conditions do abnormal attitudes emerge?"

-   Economic crisis
-   Social breakdown
-   Immigration surge
-   Political corruption
:::

. . .

::: fragment
**Implication:**

Far-right success = systemic crisis, pathological deviation from democratic norms
:::

::: notes
This was the dominant approach until Mudde (2010).

Key features: 1. Far-right attitudes seen as deviant 2. Success requires extreme conditions 3. Focus on why SOME people develop these attitudes 4. Crisis as necessary condition

Examples: - Golden Dawn = crisis (fits) - But: Austria FPÖ 1999 = no crisis (doesn't fit) - Sweden SD 2010 = prosperity (doesn't fit)

The evidence from Weeks 2-6 challenges this framework.
:::

# Part 2: Theories of Demand

## Unit of Analysis

-   Micro-level
    -   Individual level characteristics/theorisation about why
    -   Who is more likely to vote for the far-right
-   Macro-level
    -   Contextual characteristics: economy, immigration, historical and social developments
    -   Allow for explaining cross-national or cross-regional within country variation
    -   Allow for explaining similar developments in different conditions

### Common characteristic
:::

::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out}
```{r}
# 1. Prepare data and calculate proportions
immi_effect <- ess_analysis %>%
  mutate(
    # Create the categories
    immi_cat = case_when(
      p_immi_index < 30 ~ "Liberal",
      p_immi_index >= 30 & p_immi_index < 70 ~ "Neutral",
      p_immi_index >= 70 ~ "Restrictive"
    ),
    # Ensure far_right is a 0/1 numeric for mean calculation
    far_right_num = as.numeric(far_right == "Far-right")
  ) %>%
  filter(!is.na(immi_cat), !is.na(far_right_num)) %>%
  # Calculate % of far-right voters within each category
  group_by(immi_cat) %>%
  summarise(
    pct_far_right = mean(far_right_num) * 100,
    n = n()
  ) %>%
  # Calculate difference from the 'Liberal' baseline
  mutate(
    baseline = pct_far_right[immi_cat == "Liberal"],
    diff_from_liberal = pct_far_right - baseline,
    immi_cat = factor(immi_cat, levels = c("Liberal", "Neutral", "Restrictive"))
  )

# 2. Plot the "Strength of Association"
ggplot(immi_effect, aes(x = immi_cat, y = diff_from_liberal, fill = immi_cat)) +
  geom_col(width = 0.6) +
  geom_text(aes(label = paste0("+", round(diff_from_liberal, 1), " pp")), 
            vjust = -0.5, fontface = "bold") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Liberal" = "#3498DB", "Neutral" = "#F1C40F", "Restrictive" = "#E74C3C")) +
  labs(
    title = "Strength of Association: Immigration & Far-Right Vote",
    subtitle = "Increase in likelihood of far-right voting compared to 'Liberal' voters",
    x = "Immigration Attitude",
    y = "Percentage Point Difference",
    fill = "Attitude"
  ) +
  theme_solarized()

```
:::

## Economic Grievances (cont.)

**If economic crisis drives far-right success, we should see uniform surge after 2008**

::: fragment
```{r crisis-plot}
#| echo: false
#| fig-width: 10
#| fig-height: 6
#| message: false
#| warning: false


# Calculate far-right vote share per election (parfam=70)
far_right_elections <- mp_data_eu |>
  mutate(year = year(as.Date(edate))) |>
  filter(year >= 2004 & year <= 2014, parfam == 70) |>
  group_by(countryname, year, edate) |>
  summarise(far_right = sum(pervote, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop") |>
  group_by(countryname, year) |>
  slice_min(edate, n = 1) |>
  ungroup()

# Pre-crisis: last election 2004-2008
pre_crisis <- far_right_elections |>
  filter(year >= 2004 & year <= 2008) |>
  group_by(countryname) |>
  slice_max(year, n = 1) |>
  select(countryname, year_pre = year, far_right_pre = far_right) |>
  ungroup()

# Post-crisis: last election 2009-2013
post_crisis <- far_right_elections |>
  filter(year >= 2009 & year <= 2013) |>
  group_by(countryname) |>
  slice_max(year, n = 1) |>
  select(countryname, year_post = year, far_right_post = far_right) |>
  ungroup()

# Compare and add tooltips
crisis_comparison <- pre_crisis |>
  inner_join(post_crisis, by = "countryname") |>
  filter(countryname != "Cyprus") |>
  mutate(
    change = far_right_post - far_right_pre,
    region = case_when(
      countryname %in% c("Denmark", "Finland", "Norway", "Sweden") ~ "Nordic",
      countryname %in% c("Austria", "Belgium", "France", "Germany", 
                         "Netherlands", "Switzerland", "United Kingdom") ~ "Western",
      countryname %in% c("Greece", "Italy", "Portugal", "Spain") ~ "Southern",
      TRUE ~ "Eastern"
    ),
    tooltip_text = paste0(
      "<b>", countryname, "</b><br>",
      "Pre-crisis (", year_pre, "): ", round(far_right_pre, 1), "%<br>",
      "Post-crisis (", year_post, "): ", round(far_right_post, 1), "%<br>",
      "<b>Change: ", ifelse(change > 0, "+", ""), round(change, 1), " pp</b>"
    )
  )

# Create interactive plot
p <- ggplot(crisis_comparison, 
       aes(x = reorder(countryname, change), y = change, fill = region,
           text = tooltip_text)) +
  geom_col(width = 0.7) +
  coord_flip() +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0, linetype = "dashed", linewidth = 0.8, color = "gray30") +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set2", name = NULL) +
  labs(
    title = "Change in Far-Right Vote Share Around Financial Crisis",
    subtitle = "Last election 2004-2008 vs. last election 2009-2013",
    x = NULL,
    y = "Percentage Point Change",
    caption = "Data: Manifesto Project (parfam=70)"
  ) +
  theme_solarized(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    legend.position = "bottom",
    panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(),
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 15)
  )

# Convert to interactive
ggplotly(p, tooltip = "text") %>%
  layout(autosize = FALSE, width = 900, height = 500)
```

## Welfare State Matters (Vlandas and Halikiopoulou, 2016)

::: fragment
**Key insight: It's not about aggregate crisis severity**
:::

::: fragment
**It's about institutional structures that create vulnerability**
:::

::::::: columns
:::: {.column width="50%"}
**Their argument:**

::: incremental
-   Focus on **labour market risk**
-   And **welfare state generosity**
-   Interaction creates vulnerability
-   Some workers more exposed than others
:::
::::

:::: {.column width="50%"}
**The mechanism:**

::: incremental
-   High labour market flexibility = high risk
-   Low welfare generosity = low protection
-   **High risk + Low welfare** = vulnerability
-   Vulnerable workers → far-right
:::
::::
:::::::

## The Psychology of Vulnerability: Status & Decline


::: {.fragment .fade-in}
#### 1. Subjective Social Status

**Gidron & Hall (2017):** It's not just money; it's **social respect**. Low subjective rank drives the demand.
:::

::: {.fragment .fade-in}
#### 2. Downward Mobility

**Gugushvili et al. (2025):** The **trajectory** matters. Moving from high to low class creates acute resentment.
:::

::: {.fragment .fade-in}
#### 3. The Fear of Falling

**Engler & Weisstanner (2021):** Inequality creates a "threat of decline" that mobilizes even the **middle class**.
:::

::: {.fragment .fade-in}

immigration_comparison <- ess_analysis %>%
  # Filter for relevant countries and create region grouping
  filter(!is.na(region_eu)) %>%
  group_by(region_eu) %>%
  summarise(
    # Average net migration rate
    net_migration = mean(net_mig_wpp, na.rm = TRUE),
    
    # Anti-immigration attitudes (using immigration attitudes from ESS)
    # Lower values = more restrictive, so we'll reverse to show "anti-immigration"
    anti_immigration_attitude =  mean(p_immi_index, na.rm = TRUE), # Scale to percentage
    
    # Average far-right vote share
    far_right_vote = mean(fr_vote_actual, na.rm = TRUE),
    
    .groups = "drop"
  ) %>%
  # Pivot longer for faceting
  pivot_longer(
    cols = c(net_migration, anti_immigration_attitude, far_right_vote),
    names_to = "variable",
    values_to = "value"
  ) %>%
  # Create nice labels
  mutate(
    variable = case_when(
      variable == "net_migration" ~ "Net Migration Rate (per 1000)",
      variable == "anti_immigration_attitude" ~ "Anti-Immigration Attitudes (%)",
      variable == "far_right_vote" ~ "Far-Right Vote Share (%)"
    ),
    variable = factor(variable, levels = c(
      "Net Migration Rate (per 1000)",
      "Anti-Immigration Attitudes (%)",
      "Far-Right Vote Share (%)"

# Conclusions

## Summary: The Drivers of Far-Right Support {vertical-align="center"}

::::::: {layout="[[1,1], [1, 1]]"}
::: {.fragment .fade-up style="border: 1px solid #ddd; padding: 15px; border-radius: 8px;"}
#### 1. Beyond "Protest"

Far-right voting reflects stable **ideological preferences**rather than just temporary frustration.
:::

::: {.fragment .fade-up style="border: 1px solid #ddd; padding: 15px; border-radius: 8px;"}
#### 2. Economic vs. Cultural Grievances

-   *Economic:* Insecurity and relative deprivation fuel support.
-   *Cultural:* Values regarding gender, cosmopolitanism, and multiculturalism are often the primary drivers.
:::

::: {.fragment .fade-up style="border: 1px solid #ddd; padding: 15px; border-radius: 8px;"}
#### 3. Cultural Grievances vs. Contact

-   *Cultural Threat:* Perceptions of threat can drive support.
-   *Contact/Cosmopolitanism:* Local interaction can reduce prejudice.
-   *Geographic Variance:* Patterns in Eastern Europe and Germany suggest complex "threat" stories.
:::

::: {.fragment .fade-in style="text-align: center; background-color: #f8f9fa; padding: 20px; border-radius: 8px;"}
#### 4. So what then?

**Demand is necessary, but is it sufficient?**
:::
:::::::
